Award.AbstractNarration:
The annual Geometry Festival is one of the main conferences in the area of Geometry- Topology. Its aim is to expose and explain the major recent accomplishments in the field to a diverse audience of interested students and faculty, and to advance discoveries in the field by bringing together present and future experts in a supportive atmosphere, with special attention to and financial support for under-represented groups, graduate students, and young faculty.

Since 1985, the Geometry Festival has been held in rotation at the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Maryland, the University of North Carolina, the State University of New York at Stony Brook, Duke University and New York University's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.

Project Title: Geometry Festival

 

GEOMETRY FESTIVAL

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT for DMS 1010788

 

The annual Geometry Festival has been held since 1985 at the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Maryland, the University of North Carolina, Duke University, the State University of New York at Stony Brook, New York University's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences and Northeastern University. 

The list of host schools has now been expanded to include Princeton University, who hosted the latest conference April 8 - 10, 2016. 

The website for that conference can be found at

https://web.math.princeton.edu/conference/geofest2016/ 

This three day conference focuses on the major recent results in geometry and related fields.  There are typically seven or eight invited one-hour talks, no parallel sessions, and ample opportunity and space for groups to get together for discussion.  

In recent years, the Geometry Festival has devoted special attention to open problems, current directions and future opportunities in the field, and speakers are asked to direct a portion of their talks to these issues.  

The NSF Geometry Festival grant provides partial support for graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, invited speakers and persons from under-represented groups to attend the conference.  Facilities at the Geometry Festival are handicapped-accessible.
